elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: yo. u there?

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: yeah. what's up?

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: got something juicy

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: like, I can't believe this is real.

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: found creds for one of TELCO's external machines

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: u serious?

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: how'd u pull that off?

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: went trashing with nomadic at TELCO HQ

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: we spent HOURS digging thru garbage, but worth every second

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: haven't even gone through all of it yet. might be more goodies.

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: hahaha, nice work

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: so... wanna take a peek?

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: u don't wanna do the honors?

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: nah, got something even better cooking up ;)

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: lolol

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: yeah, send em

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: [file sent: telco_creds.txt]

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: got it

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: btw, they use something called 'TELNIX'. i guess it's a UNIX variant.

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: how's your UNIX-fu these days?

elements.speaker: a1rsh1p
elements.text: rusty af, tbh. mind giving me a quick refresher?

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: yeah one sec, log onto the sandbox machine

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: cool, so the first thing to run is the 'help' command

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: that will show u all the other commands you can run, as the current user on that machine

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: go ahead, run it here

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: nice

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: use that when u first bust in to see what's available

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: alright, now try 'users'

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: awesome. that shows you everyone that's on the machine. good to know who to target

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: speaking of, try to log in as that 'user' user with the auth command: auth user:password

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: seems to have worked - try the 'whoami' command to see who you are logged in as

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: pwned

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: ok now that you are authenticated as a real user, try 'help' again

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: nice, see the new commands? 'user' can run a lot more than 'guest'

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: in TELNIX, files are organized in a "filesystem". the filesystem is basically one giant folder, which can contain smaller folder or files

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: for example '/' is the root directory, '/home' is a directory inside the root directory, and '/home/msg.txt' is a file inside the 'home' directory.

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: you can view your current directory with the pwd command (print working directory)

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: the next command i wanna show you is the list command: ls

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: that one will display the files in your current directory

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: run it with the '-l' option to show file permissions tool: ls -l

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: you can also pass the name of a directory to ls to view the contents of that directory instead of your current directory

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: try it, with that .trash folder: ls .trash

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: cool. looks like there is an old file in the trash. you can read it with the 'cat' command: cat .trash/old.txt

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: don't ask me why it's called that...

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: last thing ill show u is changing directories. this changes your current directory to whatever you specified

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: try changing into the root directory: cd /

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: nice. you can pass a full directory path, or a path relative to your current working directory.

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: run ls again, i'll show u what i mean

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: ok see that 'home' folder? cd into it: cd home

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: now run pwd again

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: see how your working directory has changed?

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: ok, that's all u need to know.

elements.speaker: execut0r
elements.text: i'm connecting you to TELCO1 rn. the creds I found are telco1:telco1

args: WELCOME TO TELCO1. TYPE 'HELP' TO BEGIN:
